0.1 Line of Charge

0.2 Line of Charge at Angle

A line of charge with a charge density of Î» \lambda Î» lies along the line z = m x z=m x z=mx, where m m m is a constant, and extends from x = âˆ’ a x=-a x=âˆ’a to x = a x=a x=a.

  1. What is the expected (general) direction of E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z)? How is this direction expected to change as z z z increases?

  2. For z > > a z >> a z>>a, what should E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) approach? (Give exact equation in terms of the parameters and coordinate system given in the problem.)

  3. For z < < a z << a z<<a, what should E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) approach? (Give exact equation in terms of the parameters and coordinate system given in the problem.)

  4. Find an integral that must be solved to find E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z). See the [[F19/Notes#Continuous_Charge_Distributions|note in Step 4]] about integrals with primed variables that donâ€™t have a corresponding primed differential variable.

Answer

This problem is similar to a problem in [[F19/Notes#Continuous_Charge_Distributions|sample problems for continuous charge distributions in the notes]]. The difference is that in the sample problem

  1. the line was at an angle Î± \alpha Î± in the x âˆ’ y x-y xâˆ’y plane

  2. the points of interest were along the y y y-axis

and in this problem

  1. the line follows the equation z = m x z=mx z=mx so that the length of the line is 2 a 2 + ( a m ) 2 = 2 a 1 + m 2 2\sqrt{a^2+(am)^2}=2a\sqrt{1+m^2} 2a2+(am)2â€‹=2a1+m2â€‹

  2. the points of interest are along the z z z-axis

Instead of the relationship y â€² = x â€² tan â¡ Î± y'=x'\tan\alpha yâ€²=xâ€²tanÎ±, the relationship is z â€² = m x â€² z'=mx' zâ€²=mxâ€². So anywhere tan â¡ Î± \tan\alpha tanÎ± appears in the sample problem, it can be replaced with m m m and any y y y, y â€² y' yâ€², and y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^â€‹ can be replaced with z z z, z â€² z' zâ€², and z ^ \hat{\mathbf{z}} z^, respectively. The final answer is

E ( z ) = âˆ« âˆ’ a a d x â€² 1 + m 2 4 Ï€ Ïµ 0 âˆ’ x â€² x ^ + ( z âˆ’ m x â€² ) z ^ ( x â€² 2 + ( z âˆ’ m x â€² ) 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}(z) = \int_{-a}^{a}\frac{dx'\sqrt{1+m^2}}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{-x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+(z-mx')\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{\big(x'^2 + (z-mx')^2\big)^{3/2}} E(z)=âˆ«âˆ’aaâ€‹4Ï€Ïµ0â€‹dxâ€²1+m2â€‹â€‹(xâ€²2+(zâˆ’mxâ€²)2)3/2âˆ’xâ€²x^+(zâˆ’mxâ€²)z^â€‹

For question #2., at z â‰« a z\gg a zâ‰«a, the answer of â€œ0â€ is technically correct, but the problem statement asks for an equation in terms of the parameters given in the problem. Examples of this were given in class, in example 2.2 of Griffiths, and in the notes. The answer I was looking for is E ( z ) = y ^ k q â€² / y 2 \mathbf{E}(z)=\hat{\mathbf{y}}kq'/y^2 E(z)=y^â€‹kqâ€²/y2, where q â€² = Î» L = Î» 2 a 2 + ( a m ) 2 = Î» 2 a 1 + m 2 q'=\lambda L = \lambda 2\sqrt{a^2+(am)^2}=\lambda 2a\sqrt{1+m^2} qâ€²=Î»L=Î»2a2+(am)2â€‹=Î»2a1+m2â€‹. So that in terms of the parameters given in the problem statement,

E ( z ) = k Î» 2 a 1 + m 2 y 2 y ^ \mathbf{E}(z)=\frac{k\lambda 2a\sqrt{1+m^2}}{y^2}\hat{\mathbf{y}} E(z)=y2kÎ»2a1+m2â€‹â€‹y^â€‹

For question #3., at z â‰ª a z\ll a zâ‰ªa, the point is just above the center of the line and the system â€œlooksâ€ like an infinite line of charge, so the infinite line of charge equation applies. The electric field at this point will be perpendicular to the line. If s s s is the perpendicular distance from the center of the line, then E ( s ) = ( 1 / 2 Ï€ Ïµ o ) s ^ / s \mathbf{E}(s)=(1/2\pi\epsilon_o)\hat{\mathbf{s}}/s E(s)=(1/2Ï€Ïµoâ€‹)s^/s. Some students used this equation with z z z instead of s s s.

To get an exact equation in terms of the parameters and coordinate system of the problem, one needs to write s ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} s^ and s s s in terms of parameters and the coordinate system given in the problem of x x x, z z z, and m m m: s = âˆ’ z ( âˆ’ x ^ + z ^ / m ) \mathbf{s}=-z(-\hat{\mathbf{x}}+\hat{\mathbf{z}}/m) s=âˆ’z(âˆ’x^+z^/m). I gave full credit if it was recognized that at z â‰ª a z\ll a zâ‰ªa, the field should be perpendicular to the line. Some students said the field would be zero because these points are on the line - this is not correct - z â‰ª a z\ll a zâ‰ªa means just above the infinitely thin line; only z = 0 z = 0 z=0 would be exactly on the line.

0.3 Line of Charge with Parabolic Shape

A line of charge with a charge density of Î» \lambda Î» has a parabolic shape of z = x 2 z=x^2 z=x2 and extends from x = âˆ’ a x=-a x=âˆ’a to x = a x=a x=a.

  1. What is the expected direction of E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z)?

  2. For z > > a z >> a z>>a, what should E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) approach? (Give exact equation in terms of the parameters and coordinate system given in the problem.)

  3. Find an integral that must be solved to find E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z). See the [[F19/Notes#Continuous_Charge_Distributions|note in Step 4]] about integrals with primed variables that donâ€™t have a corresponding primed differential variable.

Answer

  1. For z > 0 z>0 z>0, expect E \mathbf{E} E to be in + z ^ +\hat{\mathbf{z}} +z^ direction (I gave full credit for this answer, but some correctly noted that there may be a point for small enough z where it is actually in âˆ’ z ^ -\hat{\mathbf{z}} âˆ’z^ direction). For z > 0 z>0 z>0, expect E \mathbf{E} E to be in âˆ’ z ^ -\hat{\mathbf{z}} âˆ’z^ direction. The on the z-axis, the electric field has no component in the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ direction because a charge at position x = x o x=x_o x=xoâ€‹ produces an electric field with a component in the âˆ’ x ^ -\hat{\mathbf{x}} âˆ’x^ direction that is canceled by that from a charge at x = âˆ’ x o x=-x_o x=âˆ’xoâ€‹. The electric field component in the z z z-direction for both of these charges are in the + z +z +z direction. (Draw this.)

  2. When z > > a z>>a z>>a, the distance from all d q â€² s dq's dqâ€²s to the point of interest at z z z is approximately z z z and so Coulombâ€™s Law for a charge Q Q Q at the origin applies: E = k Q â€² / z 2 E=kQ'/z^2 E=kQâ€²/z2, where Q â€² Q' Qâ€² is the total charge on the line. Q â€² Q' Qâ€² needs to be written in terms of the parameters of the problem - it is Q â€² = Î» L Q' = \lambda L Qâ€²=Î»L where L L L is the length of the line that will depend on a a a. Computing the length of the line requires integration and I gave full credit is this was recognized but L L L was not calculated. The general formula for the length of a line that follows a path P \mathcal{P} P is

L = âˆ« P d l L = \int_{\mathcal{P}} dl L=âˆ«Pâ€‹dl

The integration requires writing d l dl dl and the limits of integration in terms of a coordinate system.

The general formula for a differential element in cartesian coordinates is

d l = d x x ^ + d z z ^ d\mathbf{l} = dx\hat{\mathbf{x}} + dz\hat{\mathbf{z}} dl=dxx^+dzz^

which has a magnitude

d l = ( d x ) 2 + ( d z ) 2 dl = \sqrt{(dx)^2+(dz)^2} dl=(dx)2+(dz)2â€‹

factoring out d x dx dx gives a formula that may be familiar from path integration in a calculus course

d l = d x 1 + ( d z d x ) 2 dl = dx\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{dz}{dx}\right)^2} dl=dx1+(dxdzâ€‹)2â€‹

so the length of the differential element depends on the slope of the line d z / d x dz/dx dz/dx. For this particular problem, the line follows the path P \mathcal{P} P according to the equation z = x 2 z=x^2 z=x2, so d z / d x = 2 x dz/dx = 2x dz/dx=2x. Substitution gives

d l = d x 1 + 4 x 2 dl = dx\sqrt{1+4x^2} dl=dx1+4x2â€‹

This d l dl dl can now be used to perform the integration of the general equation

L = âˆ« P d l = âˆ« âˆ’ a a d x 1 + 4 x 2 L = \int_{\mathcal{P}} dl = \int_{-a}^{a}dx\sqrt{1+4x^2} L=âˆ«Pâ€‹dl=âˆ«âˆ’aaâ€‹dx1+4x2â€‹

The integral can be perfomed using a x = ( tan â¡ u ) / 2 x=(\tan u)/2 x=(tanu)/2 substitution and appears in many references - the key that I am looking in solutions is the recognition that computing the total charge in terms of the parameters given requires integration and the set-up of the integral.

  1. Step 1

d l dl dl was already computed previously and so

d q â€² = Î» d l â€² = d x â€² 1 + 4 x â€² 2 dq'=\lambda dl'= dx'\sqrt{1+4x'^2} dqâ€²=Î»dlâ€²=dxâ€²1+4xâ€²2â€‹

where primes are used following the convention that position variables associated with charges are primed.

Step 2

In general,

Answers to 3.-6.

3. There are three general ways to do this:

1. Starting from the basic formula for the electric field due to a charge d q dq dq and summing contributions from d q dq dqs at all locations on the disk. This will involve a double integral. 2. Integrating over contributions from rings of charge. This will involve a single integral over contributions of rings of different sizes and knowledge of the electric field due to a ring of charge. 3. Computing V V V first and using E = âˆ’ âˆ‡ V \mathbf{E}=-\nabla V E=âˆ’âˆ‡V.

Iâ€™ll follow method 1. and Iâ€™ll note that one of the formulas found as the solution is developed is the same one you would get if you started with 2. Method 3. would be useful if I asked you to solve the integral, which I am not going to do on an exam. (But there is a trick that I have not showed you that you could use on the exam where you can write V V V in terms of an integral and then differentiate it. The x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ and y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^â€‹ integrals are zero because their integrands are odd functions. Many students argued they are zero â€œby symmetryâ€. The word â€œsymmetryâ€ is too general because there are many types of symmetry. It is better to state what kind of symmetry: consider differential charges at ( x , y ) (x,y) (x,y) and ( âˆ’ x , âˆ’ y ) (-x,-y) (âˆ’x,âˆ’y) - their horizontal electric fields exactly cancel (ideally provide a diagram). The sheet of charge can be constructed by placing charges with canceling horizontal components and so the horizontal electric field is zero.
